results.title: Melody in music
results.brief_description: A school instrumental ensemble consisting of violin, tuba, piccolo, flute, chimes, piano, cornet and French horn, learn the importance of melody in music. The film hows how variations in note arrangement, lyrics, different music instruments, note length, and tune all effect the melody. Students are encouraged to make their own melodies by learning how other melodies are developed. The film concludes with a performance by the ensemble of a simplified arrangement of the final movement of the Brahms First Symphony.

results.title: Melodies that linger
results.brief_description: A straightforward presentation of 40s vintage pop songs - “Number 10 Lullaby Lane” featuring singer Marilyn Stuart; “A Lover Is Blue”, Tommy Reynolds and his orchestra with Phyllis Lane the singer; “Penthouse Serenade” with singers Johnny Downs and Gale Storm.

results.title: Melodie En Sous-Sol = the Big Snatch (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
An ex-con sets up one last job and enlists the help of a younger crook to rob the Casino at Cannes. Everything goes according to plan, right up to the last minute until … A very standard caper film which gives one more opportunity to the trio Verneuil-Gabin-Audiard to send up the gangster genre with razor-sharp one-liners. Like his illustrious predecessors Henri Jeanson and Jacques Prevert, Audiard mixed classic French and slang and delighted in derision and ‘bons mots’, though his dialogue was coarser (a sign of the times) and more schocking. (…) Audiard’s witty, hard-hitting dialogue underpins much of the best popular French cinema from the late 1950s to the mid-1980s, notably his collaborations with Jean Gabin, for whom he wrote tailor-made dialogue.” Reference: Ginette Vincendeau. The companion to French cinema. BFI Publishing, 1996.

Credits: Producer, Jacques Juranville ; director, Henri Verneuil ; writers, Albert Simonin, Michel Audiard ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Michel Magne.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Alain Delon, Maurice Biraud, Viviane Romance, Henri Virlojeux, Germaine Montero, Jean Carmet, Dora Doll.

results.title: Melo
results.brief_description: Pierre and Maniche are happily married until she meets Marcel, Pierre’s friend. Romaine and Marcel have an affair which ends tragically. Pierre remarries and before leaving the country he visits Marcel to learn the truth about Romaine. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Melbourne: Australia's garden city
results.brief_description: This panoramic tour of Victoria’s capital provides the viewer with a vibrant snapshot of Melbourne and its surroundings. Highlights of the tour include: a trip on Melbourne’s famous trams, beautiful parks and gardens, historic landmarks Como House and Werribee Park, Cook’s Cottage in the scenic Fitzroy gardens, Old Melbourne Gaol, the Dandenongs and Puffing Billy, Marysville, Sovereign Hill, Ballarat and surrounds, the National Wool Museum at Geelong, Phillip Island and the tranquil bush surroundings of Healesville Sanctuary.

results.title: Melbourne rising (D): S-11 protests against the World Economic Forum
results.brief_description: This independently made documentary follows the three day Asia Pacific Economic Summit (World Economic Forum) held at Melbourne’s Crown Casino from September 11-13, 2000 and the events that took place between the S-11 protesters and the Victorian Police during those three days. The camera has captured some rather up-close and disturbing images of the physical violence dealt by the police to the protesters, particularly in the first two days of the Summit. It was estimated that over 10,000 protesters managed to prevent 150-200 participants from attending the Summit on Day 1. This led to a heightened reaction from the Police on Day 2 resulting in the injuring and hospitalisation of 30 protesters. By Day 3, with a smaller crowd of protesters in attendance, and a somewhat calmer atmosphere between police and protesters, the focus of S-11 turned to the effects of globalisation on women and indigenous people around the world. The film features footage and interviews with several of the protesters, union leaders, local entities, politicians including Richard Court (Premier W.A.), Steve Bracks (Premier, Vic.), Denis Napthine (Opp. Leader, Vic.), Bob Brown (Sen. Aust. Greens), Peter Costello (Aust. Fed. Treasurer) and inside footage of speakers at the Summit, the highlight of which was Dr Vandana Shiva speaking on behalf of the young people of Australia and the world. The three-day non-violent campaign by S-11 protesters against globalisation was witnessed by the international media, including the BBC, subsequently putting Melbourne on the world stage, alongside Seattle, in the voicing of its opposition to the WEF and what it stands for. WARNING: Contains images that may be distressing and language that may offend some viewers.

results.title: Melbourne prepares for Olympic Games
results.brief_description: Originally produced for BBC Television, this film is a progress report on preparations for the XVIth Olympiad, 1956. At the Melbourne Cricket Ground, the main stadium for the Games, new triple-deck steel and concrete stands are under construction, the five acre arena has been completely regraded and foundations laid for running tracks. This stadium, the scene for the opening ceremony, the track and field events, the soccer and hockey finals will hold a record Olympic crowd of 110,000. At nearby Olympic Park, new arenas and racing tracks are under construction. Also in close proximity to the main stadium is the Olympic Swimming Pool, an unusual structure of ultramodern design in which roofing and sloping sides without conventional pillars, support seating for 5,000 spectators. At Heidelberg, Olympic Village is nearing completion, for the first time in the history of the Games, competing athletes of both sexes and from all countries will live together at the Village for the duration of the Games.
